Igor Bonifacic Senior reporter Updated Tue, January 6, 2026 at 2:30 PM UTC Add Engadget on Google NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang presents at CES 2026, wearing a black snakeskin-like jacket. (NVIDIA) Jensen Huang took to the CES stage on Monday to share the latest from NVIDIA, and while the presentation was more a refresher of technologies the company has been working on for the past few years, there were a couple of notable announcements. NVIDIA announced Alpamayo, a family of open-source reasoning models designed to guide autonomous vehicles through difficult driving situations. The centerpiece of the release is Alpamayo 1 , a 10-billion parameter chain-of-thought system NVIDIA says is capable of approaching driving more like a human being would. The model works by breaking down unexpected driving situations into a smaller set of problems before finding the safest path forward. At each step of the way, the model can explain its reasoning. A sister model named AlpaSim allows developers to do closed-loop training for driving scenarios that are rarely encountered in real life. Huang said the 2025 Mercedes Benz CLA will be the first vehicle to ship with NVIDIAs entire AV stack, including Alpamayo. "Our vision is that someday, every single car, every single truck, will be autonomous," Huang said. Advertisement Advertisement Following the Alpamayo announcements, a pair of BD-1 droids from Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order joined Huang on stage. We saw one join the executive at last years CES. After that, Huang turned to Vera Rubin. NVIDIA first announced the GPU architecture in 2024 , and now the company has begun production on a super computer that makes use of the new tech. One Vera CPU has 88 custom Olympus cores and 1.5TB of system memory for a total of 227 billion transistors. Meanwhile, one Rubin GPU features 336 billion transistors. Each Vera Rubin supercomputer has a pair of both components. Following the presentation, NVIDIA held a separate briefing where it announced DLSS 4.5 and G-Sync Pulsar . The latest version of NVIDIAs upscaling technology was trained on a second-generation transformer model, which should reduce ghosting and shimmering, leading to a more stable image, even when theres a lot of movement on screen. As part of DLSS 4.5, NVIDIA is also adding support for 6x multi-frame and dynamic generation. The two features will arrive sometime in the spring. The former allows a 50-series GPU to generate five frames for every traditionally rendered frame. The idea here is to allow a powerful GPU like the RTX 5090 to saturate a 4K, 240HZ display with as many frames as possible. Dynamic frame generation, meanwhile, is exactly what it sounds like. DLSS 4.5 can dynamically scale the number of generated frames to fit the scenario. In demanding scenes, your 50-series GPU will generate more frames, while scaling back during less hectic ones so it only computes what it needs. As for G-Sync Pulsar , its the latest improvement to NVIDIAs flicker reduction technology. By pulsing a displays backlight, NVIDIA says it can deliver perceived motion clarity relative to 1,000Hz, leading to greater clarity. Those same displays will also ship with the ability to automatically adjust their brightness and color temperature to ambient lighting conditions. Pre-orders for the first batch of G-Sync Pulsar displays will open on January 7. Update 01/06/26 9:30AM : Added information about DLSS 4.5 and G-SYNC Pulsar. Were not even a full week into 2026 yet, but Nvidia has already announced several products and updates to start the new year. Nvidias new Vera Rubin architecture was launched earlier than expected at CES , joined by announcements for its own Tesla-rivaling self-driving car technology, and the latest updates coming to DLSS, G-Sync display tech, and the GeForce Now cloud gaming platform. While none of these hold quite the same appeal as a new generation of consumer graphics cards something we might see at CES 2027, following the RTX 50-series launch last year it can still be a lot to parse, especially through the vast slurry of everything else being promoted at the giant Consumer Electronics Show. Weve rounded up the most significant announcements that Nvidia has made so far to help you stay on top of the news. Vera Rubin Supercomputer: A next-generation successor to the Blackwell architecture, with 88 custom Olympus cores (CPU) and a Rubin GPU featuring 336 billion transistors per GPU. Each supercomputer contains a pair of both components.
DLSS 4.5: Enhanced deep learning super sampling trained on a second-generation transformer model, reducing ghosting and shimmering, and adding support for 6x multi-frame and dynamic generation.

globals_schema.nvidia_ces_2026_launch_report_T004:
NVIDIA Product Launches at CES 2026

Executive Summary

NVIDIA made several significant announcements at CES 2026, showcasing advancements in autonomous vehicle technology, supercomputing, and gaming display technology. Key highlights include the introduction of Alpamayo, a family of open-source reasoning models for autonomous vehicles; the Vera Rubin Supercomputer, a next-generation successor to the Blackwell architecture; DLSS 4.5, an enhanced deep learning super sampling technology; and G-Sync Pulsar, an improvement to NVIDIA's flicker reduction technology. This report provides a detailed overview of these product launches, including key features, specifications, and potential impact.

Table of Contents

  • Alpamayo: Open-Source Reasoning Models for Autonomous Vehicles
  • Vera Rubin Supercomputer: Next-Generation Architecture
  • DLSS 4.5: Enhanced Deep Learning Super Sampling
  • G-Sync Pulsar: Improved Flicker Reduction Technology

Alpamayo: Open-Source Reasoning Models for Autonomous Vehicles

Alpamayo is a family of open-source reasoning models designed for autonomous vehicles. The centerpiece of this release is Alpamayo 1, a 10-billion parameter chain-of-thought system. According to NVIDIA, Alpamayo 1 is capable of approaching driving more like a human being would, by breaking down unexpected driving situations into a smaller set of problems before finding the safest path forward. The model also explains its reasoning at each step, offering transparency and accountability in autonomous driving decisions.

A sister model, AlpaSim, allows developers to conduct closed-loop training for driving scenarios that are rarely encountered in real life. This enables more robust testing and validation of autonomous driving systems in a virtual environment before deployment in real-world conditions. NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang announced that the 2025 Mercedes Benz CLA will be the first vehicle to ship with NVIDIA's entire AV stack, including Alpamayo, marking a significant milestone in the adoption of AI in the automotive industry. Huang stated, "Our vision is that someday, every single car, every single truck, will be autonomous," highlighting NVIDIA's long-term commitment to autonomous driving technology. According to Engadget, the Alpamayo models are designed to guide autonomous vehicles through difficult driving situations, a crucial step towards achieving full autonomy. The ability of the model to explain its reasoning is particularly important for building trust and ensuring safety in autonomous driving systems.

Vera Rubin Supercomputer: Next-Generation Architecture

The Vera Rubin Supercomputer represents NVIDIA's next-generation successor to the Blackwell architecture. Each Vera CPU features 88 custom Olympus cores and 1.5TB of system memory, totaling 227 billion transistors. Meanwhile, each Rubin GPU contains 336 billion transistors. A complete Vera Rubin supercomputer comprises a pair of both components, delivering unparalleled computing power for AI and high-performance computing workloads.

NVIDIA first announced the GPU architecture in 2024, and production has now commenced on the supercomputer that utilizes this new technology. This advancement is expected to significantly enhance NVIDIA's capabilities in AI research, development, and deployment. According to The Verge, the Vera Rubin launch was earlier than expected at CES 2026, underscoring NVIDIA's commitment to pushing the boundaries of computing technology. The supercomputer's architecture is designed to handle the most demanding AI workloads, making it a valuable tool for researchers and developers working on cutting-edge AI applications.

DLSS 4.5: Enhanced Deep Learning Super Sampling

DLSS 4.5 is the latest iteration of NVIDIA's Deep Learning Super Sampling technology, building upon previous versions to deliver enhanced image quality and performance in gaming and other graphically intensive applications. This version is trained on a second-generation transformer model, which significantly reduces ghosting and shimmering artifacts that can occur with upscaling techniques.

According to NVIDIA's announcement at CES 2026, DLSS 4.5 adds support for 6x multi-frame generation and dynamic generation. The 6x multi-frame feature allows a 50-series GPU to generate five frames for every traditionally rendered frame, enabling powerful GPUs like the RTX 5090 to saturate high-refresh-rate displays with as many frames as possible. Dynamic frame generation dynamically scales the number of generated frames to fit the scenario. In demanding scenes, the GPU will generate more frames, while scaling back during less hectic ones to optimize performance and power consumption. This ensures a smooth and responsive gaming experience across a wide range of hardware configurations.

G-Sync Pulsar: Improved Flicker Reduction Technology

G-Sync Pulsar represents NVIDIA's latest advancement in flicker reduction technology for gaming displays. By pulsing a display's backlight, G-Sync Pulsar delivers perceived motion clarity relative to 1,000Hz, resulting in greater clarity and reduced motion blur. This is particularly beneficial in fast-paced games where every millisecond counts.

In addition to improved motion clarity, G-Sync Pulsar displays will automatically adjust their brightness and color temperature to match ambient lighting conditions. This ensures optimal viewing comfort and image quality in any environment. Pre-orders for the first batch of G-Sync Pulsar displays opened on January 7, marking the availability of this cutting-edge display technology to consumers. According to NVIDIA, G-Sync Pulsar is designed to provide the most immersive and responsive gaming experience possible, setting a new standard for display technology in the gaming industry.

Igor Bonifacic Senior reporter Updated Tue, January 6, 2026 at 2:30 PM UTC Add Engadget on Google NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang presents at CES 2026, wearing a black snakeskin-like jacket. (NVIDIA) Jensen Huang took to the CES stage on Monday to share the latest from NVIDIA, and while the presentation was more a refresher of technologies the company has been working on for the past few years, there were a couple of notable announcements. NVIDIA announced Alpamayo, a family of open-source reasoning models designed to guide autonomous vehicles through difficult driving situations. The centerpiece of the release is Alpamayo 1 , a 10-billion parameter chain-of-thought system NVIDIA says is capable of approaching driving more like a human being would. The model works by breaking down unexpected driving situations into a smaller set of problems before finding the safest path forward. At each step of the way, the model can explain its reasoning. A sister model named AlpaSim allows developers to do closed-loop training for driving scenarios that are rarely encountered in real life. Huang said the 2025 Mercedes Benz CLA will be the first vehicle to ship with NVIDIAs entire AV stack, including Alpamayo. "Our vision is that someday, every single car, every single truck, will be autonomous," Huang said. Advertisement Advertisement Following the Alpamayo announcements, a pair of BD-1 droids from Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order joined Huang on stage. We saw one join the executive at last years CES. After that, Huang turned to Vera Rubin. NVIDIA first announced the GPU architecture in 2024 , and now the company has begun production on a super computer that makes use of the new tech. One Vera CPU has 88 custom Olympus cores and 1.5TB of system memory for a total of 227 billion transistors. Meanwhile, one Rubin GPU features 336 billion transistors. Each Vera Rubin supercomputer has a pair of both components. Following the presentation, NVIDIA held a separate briefing where it announced DLSS 4.5 and G-Sync Pulsar . The latest version of NVIDIAs upscaling technology was trained on a second-generation transformer model, which should reduce ghosting and shimmering, leading to a more stable image, even when theres a lot of movement on screen. As part of DLSS 4.5, NVIDIA is also adding support for 6x multi-frame and dynamic generation. The two features will arrive sometime in the spring. The former allows a 50-series GPU to generate five frames for every traditionally rendered frame. The idea here is to allow a powerful GPU like the RTX 5090 to saturate a 4K, 240HZ display with as many frames as possible. Dynamic frame generation, meanwhile, is exactly what it sounds like. DLSS 4.5 can dynamically scale the number of generated frames to fit the scenario. In demanding scenes, your 50-series GPU will generate more frames, while scaling back during less hectic ones so it only computes what it needs. As for G-Sync Pulsar , its the latest improvement to NVIDIAs flicker reduction technology. By pulsing a displays backlight, NVIDIA says it can deliver perceived motion clarity relative to 1,000Hz, leading to greater clarity. Those same displays will also ship with the ability to automatically adjust their brightness and color temperature to ambient lighting conditions. Pre-orders for the first batch of G-Sync Pulsar displays will open on January 7. Update 01/06/26 9:30AM : Added information about DLSS 4.5 and G-SYNC Pulsar. output.nvidia_ces_2026_launch_report_T004:
NVIDIA Product Launches at CES 2026

Executive Summary

NVIDIA made several significant announcements at CES 2026, showcasing advancements in autonomous vehicle technology, supercomputing, and gaming display technology. Key highlights include the introduction of Alpamayo, a family of open-source reasoning models for autonomous vehicles; the Vera Rubin Supercomputer, a next-generation successor to the Blackwell architecture; DLSS 4.5, an enhanced deep learning super sampling technology; and G-Sync Pulsar, an improvement to NVIDIA's flicker reduction technology. This report provides a detailed overview of these product launches, including key features, specifications, and potential impact.

Table of Contents

  • Alpamayo: Open-Source Reasoning Models for Autonomous Vehicles
  • Vera Rubin Supercomputer: Next-Generation Architecture
  • DLSS 4.5: Enhanced Deep Learning Super Sampling
  • G-Sync Pulsar: Improved Flicker Reduction Technology

Alpamayo: Open-Source Reasoning Models for Autonomous Vehicles

Alpamayo is a family of open-source reasoning models designed for autonomous vehicles. The centerpiece of this release is Alpamayo 1, a 10-billion parameter chain-of-thought system. According to NVIDIA, Alpamayo 1 is capable of approaching driving more like a human being would, by breaking down unexpected driving situations into a smaller set of problems before finding the safest path forward. The model also explains its reasoning at each step, offering transparency and accountability in autonomous driving decisions.

A sister model, AlpaSim, allows developers to conduct closed-loop training for driving scenarios that are rarely encountered in real life. This enables more robust testing and validation of autonomous driving systems in a virtual environment before deployment in real-world conditions. NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang announced that the 2025 Mercedes Benz CLA will be the first vehicle to ship with NVIDIA's entire AV stack, including Alpamayo, marking a significant milestone in the adoption of AI in the automotive industry. Huang stated, "Our vision is that someday, every single car, every single truck, will be autonomous," highlighting NVIDIA's long-term commitment to autonomous driving technology. According to Engadget, the Alpamayo models are designed to guide autonomous vehicles through difficult driving situations, a crucial step towards achieving full autonomy. The ability of the model to explain its reasoning is particularly important for building trust and ensuring safety in autonomous driving systems.

Vera Rubin Supercomputer: Next-Generation Architecture

The Vera Rubin Supercomputer represents NVIDIA's next-generation successor to the Blackwell architecture. Each Vera CPU features 88 custom Olympus cores and 1.5TB of system memory, totaling 227 billion transistors. Meanwhile, each Rubin GPU contains 336 billion transistors. A complete Vera Rubin supercomputer comprises a pair of both components, delivering unparalleled computing power for AI and high-performance computing workloads.

NVIDIA first announced the GPU architecture in 2024, and production has now commenced on the supercomputer that utilizes this new technology. This advancement is expected to significantly enhance NVIDIA's capabilities in AI research, development, and deployment. According to The Verge, the Vera Rubin launch was earlier than expected at CES 2026, underscoring NVIDIA's commitment to pushing the boundaries of computing technology. The supercomputer's architecture is designed to handle the most demanding AI workloads, making it a valuable tool for researchers and developers working on cutting-edge AI applications.

DLSS 4.5: Enhanced Deep Learning Super Sampling

DLSS 4.5 is the latest iteration of NVIDIA's Deep Learning Super Sampling technology, building upon previous versions to deliver enhanced image quality and performance in gaming and other graphically intensive applications. This version is trained on a second-generation transformer model, which significantly reduces ghosting and shimmering artifacts that can occur with upscaling techniques.

According to NVIDIA's announcement at CES 2026, DLSS 4.5 adds support for 6x multi-frame generation and dynamic generation. The 6x multi-frame feature allows a 50-series GPU to generate five frames for every traditionally rendered frame, enabling powerful GPUs like the RTX 5090 to saturate high-refresh-rate displays with as many frames as possible. Dynamic frame generation dynamically scales the number of generated frames to fit the scenario. In demanding scenes, the GPU will generate more frames, while scaling back during less hectic ones to optimize performance and power consumption. This ensures a smooth and responsive gaming experience across a wide range of hardware configurations.

G-Sync Pulsar: Improved Flicker Reduction Technology

G-Sync Pulsar represents NVIDIA's latest advancement in flicker reduction technology for gaming displays. By pulsing a display's backlight, G-Sync Pulsar delivers perceived motion clarity relative to 1,000Hz, resulting in greater clarity and reduced motion blur. This is particularly beneficial in fast-paced games where every millisecond counts.

In addition to improved motion clarity, G-Sync Pulsar displays will automatically adjust their brightness and color temperature to match ambient lighting conditions. This ensures optimal viewing comfort and image quality in any environment. Pre-orders for the first batch of G-Sync Pulsar displays opened on January 7, marking the availability of this cutting-edge display technology to consumers. According to NVIDIA, G-Sync Pulsar is designed to provide the most immersive and responsive gaming experience possible, setting a new standard for display technology in the gaming industry.

output.fallback_markdown: Detailed report summarizing NVIDIA's product launches at CES 2026.
